questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following best describes the actions of the muscle marked in the figure?
questions.explanation:
The muscle marked in the above image is the superior oblique. Actions of the superior oblique: • Intorsion • Depression • Abduction Longest extraocular muscle: Superior oblique Shortest extraocular muscle: Inferior oblique The primary action of a muscle is its major effect when the eye is in the primary position. Subsidiary actions are the additional effects; these depend on the position of the eye. The spiral of Tillaux is an imaginary line joining the insertions of the four recti and is an 
important anatomical landmark when performing surgery. 451 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following pair of muscles are responsible for the intorsion of the eyeball?
questions.explanation:
The muscles producing intorsion of the eyeball are the superior rectus and superior oblique. Extorsion of the eyeball is due to the action of the inferior oblique (major) and the inferior rectus 
muscle.

questions.question:
Question 3: 442 
Sold by @itachibot Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked by the arrow in the image 
given below.
questions.explanation:
The muscle marked is the medial rectus. The medial rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve, 
the nucleus of which is situated at the level of the superior colliculus in the posterior midbrain. The oculomotor (3rd cranial) nerve nucleus consists of • Single central nuclei for the levator palpebrae muscle of both the eyes • Bilateral subnuclei with crossed projections supplying the contralateral superior rectus • Bilateral subnuclei with uncrossed projections supplying the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior 
oblique, medial rectus in the dorso-ventral order. • Bilateral subnuclei known as the Edinger-Westphal nucleus which provides parasympathetic 
input to the ciliary body and the iris sphincter. Option A: Superior olivary nucleus is an important relay station in the auditory pathway, it is 
responsible for detection of direction and localization of sound. Option B: Inferior colliculus- The trochlear(4th cranial) nerve nucleus lies in the midbrain at the 
level of the inferior colliculus. The trochlear nerves leave the midbrain from its posterior surface 
and decussate before supplying the contralateral superior oblique muscle of the eyeball. Option D: Facial colliculus- the facial colliculus is located in the cranial part of the pons. It is 
produced by the facial nerve(7th cranial nerve) winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve 
(6th cranial nerve).

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following pairs constitute yoke muscles?

options.a: Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR)
options.b: Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior oblique (IO)
options.c: Right medial rectus (MR) and left medial rectus (MR)
options.d: Right medial rectus (MR) and right lateral rectus (LR)

questions.explanation:
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR) are the yoke muscle pair for 
levodepression. The term "yoke muscles" refers to contralateral synergists. Includes a pair of muscles, one from 
each eye, which contract simultaneously during version movements. Examples are: • Right MR and Left LR for levoversion • Right LR and Left MR for dextroversion An easy method to determine other yoke muscle pairs: 452 
Sold by @itachibot Just take the opposite of each word- Left  Right Superior  Inferior Oblique  Rectus “Left SO and Right IR” are a yoke muscle pair. Similarly, the following are yoke muscle pairs: • Right IO and Left SR - Levoelevation • Right SR and Left IO - Dextroelevation • Right IR and Left SO - Dextrodepression

questions.question:
Question 5: Yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is the  
.
questions.explanation:
The yoke muscle of the Right lateral rectus in right dextroversion is the left medial rectus. Yoke muscles also known as contralateral synergists include a pair of muscles, one from each eye, 
which contract simultaneously during version movements. Versions are simultaneous movements of both eyes in the same direction, such as dextroversion in 
which both the eyes move to the right. Hence, in dextroversion, the right eye is in abduction due to the action of right lateral rectus and 
the left eye is in adduction by the action of the left medial rectus. An easy method to determine yoke muscle pairs: Just take the opposite of each word- Left  Right Superior  Inferior 453 
Sold by @itachibot Oblique  Rectus “Left SO and Right IR” are a yoke muscle pair. Other examples of yoke muscles are: • Right MR and Left LR for levoversion • Right IO and Left SR - Levoelevation • Right SR and Left IO - Dextroelevation • Right IR and Left SO - Dextrodepression [IO-inferior oblique;SO-superior oblique;SR-superior rectus;IR-inferior rectus;MR-medial 
rectus;LR-lateral rectus]

questions.question:
Question 6: During ocular motility, increased flow of innervation to the contracting muscle is 
accompanied by a decreased flow of innervation to the relaxing antagonist muscle. This 
statement describes which law?
questions.explanation: The above statement elucidates Sherrington's Law of reciprocal innervation.

questions.question:
Question 7: You are an intern posted in the ophthalmology department. You are asked to check the 
cardinal fields of gaze to check the range of extraocular movements. How many cardinal 
fields are there?
questions.explanation:
There are six cardinal positions (fields) of gaze. These are the positions that allow examination of 
each of the twelve extraocular muscles. They are as follows: • Dextroversion (right lateral rectus and left medial rectus) • Laevoversion (left lateral rectus and right medial rectus) • Dextroelevation (right superior rectus and left inferior oblique) • Laevoelevation (left superior rectus and right inferior oblique) 454 
Sold by @itachibot • Dextrodepression (right inferior rectus and left superior oblique) • Laevodepression (left inferior rectus and right superior oblique) Note: There are 3 other positions, namely, normal primary position, supraversion, and 
infraversion. These are, however, not cardinal positions as the action of the muscles causing these 
positions can be elicited by the 6 cardinal positions themselves. The image below illustrates the 6 cardinal positions of gaze.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following best defines saccades?
questions.explanation:
Saccades are sudden, jerky eye movements that occur as the gaze shifts from one object to 
another. They are performed to bring the image of an object quickly on the fovea. 455 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows saccadic movement of the eyeball Eye movements that have a supranuclear control: • Saccades • Pursuits- smooth eye movements • Vergence movement system- slow, disconjugate movements • Vestibular eye movement- compensate for the effects of head movements • Optokinetic system- during sustained head rotation • Position maintenance system- consist of rapid micromovements such as flicks and drifts

questions.question:
Question 9: An ophthalmologist tests a particular phenomenon using the instrument shown below. Which 
of the following statements is false regarding the same? 444 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The phenomenon is a physiological one
options.b: Frontal lobe controls the slow pursuit movement
options.c: Reversal of optokinetic nystagmus, in congenital motor nystagmus

questions.explanation:
The given image shows an optokinetic drum used to elicit optokinetic nystagmus (OKN). The 
parieto-occipital lobe controls the slow pursuit component, whereas the frontal lobes control the 
saccadic component. OKN is normal physiological nystagmus in response to motion/continuously moving objects. It 
occurs in response to a repetitive visual stimulus moved across the visual field. The slow phase 
occurs in the direction of the moving stimulus; the fast phase occurs as a saccadic refixation 
movement in the opposite direction. In patients with congenital motor nystagmus, a reversal of 
the OKN response may occur. An OKN response elicited in a person who feigns visual loss 
indicates that visual input is present and is a malingerer.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not a nystagmoid movement?
questions.explanation:
All are nystagmoid movements except optokinetic. 456 
Sold by @itachibot Optokinetic nystagmus is a physiological nystagmus. Nystagmoid movements: • Ocular flutter • Ocular bobbing • Opsoclonus • Superior oblique myokymia

questions.question:
Question 11: A 24-year-old woman presented with progressive diminution of vision, headache, and 
unsteadiness of gait. A comprehensive clinical evaluation revealed coarse, left-beating 
nystagmus with leftward gaze and a fine primary-position right-beating nystagmus which 
increased on rightward gaze, consistent with Brun's nystagmus. What is the most likely cause 
of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Bruns nystagmus is an unusual type of bilateral nystagmus most commonly occurring in patients 
with cerebellopontine angle tumors. It is caused by the combination of slow, large-amplitude nystagmus (gaze paretic nystagmus) 
when looking towards the side of the lesion, and rapid, small amplitude nystagmus (vestibular 
nystagmus) when looking away from the side of the lesion. Option A- Cerebellar lesions and Arnold–Chiari malformation: downbeat nystagmus Options C and D- Arnold–Chiari malformation and demyelination syndromes: periodic alternating 
nystagmus (left beating nystagmus->null phase->right beating nystagmus->null phase).

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a wrong statement regarding diplopia?

options.a: Anisometropia is a cause for binocular diplopia.
options.b: Crossed diplopia occurs in convergent squint.
options.c: Incipient cataract is a cause for uniocular diplopia.
options.d: Harmonious diplopia refers to uncrossed binocular diplopia.

questions.explanation:
Crossed diplopia is seen in a divergent squint, as in medial rectus paralysis. Binocular diplopia: Simultaneous perception of two images of a single object when seen by both 
eyes. Causes: • Anisometropia • Paralysis of extraocular muscles; commonest • Mechanical restriction of movements Types: Uncrossed—Harmonious • False image on the same side of the deviation • Seen in convergent squint Crossed—Unharmonious • False image on the opposite side of the deviation • Seen in divergent squint Uniocular diplopia: Simultaneous perception of two images of a single object when seen by a 
single eye. 457 
Sold by @itachibot Causes: • Subluxated clear lens • Subluxated intraocular lens (IOL) • Double pupil • Incipient cataract • Keratoconus

questions.question: Question 13: Hirschberg test is used to detect which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The Hirschberg test is used to detect squint. The Hirschberg test gives a rough objective estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen 
torch is shone into the eyes from arm’s length, and the patient is asked to fixate on the light. The 
corneal reflection of the light will be (more or less) centered in the pupil of the fixating eye but will 
be decentred in a squinting eye, in the direction opposite to that of the deviation. The distance of 
the corneal light reflection from the center of the pupil is noted; each millimeter of the deviation is 
approximately equal to 7°. 458 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: As an intern posted in the ophthalmology department, you are performing Hirschberg's test 
on a patient who is being evaluated for strabismus. The finding observed is shown below. 
What is the angle of deviation in this patient? 446 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
From the given image of a Hirschberg test, it can be inferred that the patient has 90 prism 
dioptres (PD) of exotropia. On the Hirschberg test, if the light reflection is on the nasal limbus, it means 45 degrees 
exotropia. One degree is equal to 2 PD (prism dioptre). Therefore, 45 degrees exotropia would 
mean 90 PD exotropia in the right eye.

questions.question:
Question 15: You are evaluating a case of strabismus in a 3-year-old child. Which of the following tests 
would you use to assess binocular single vision?
questions.explanation:
Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore. Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated 
use of both eyes so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated 
as a single image by the process of fusion. The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both 
eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the 
presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 
years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression. 459 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which grade of binocular vision does the following image represent?
questions.explanation: The given image depicts Grade II of binocular vision, fusion.

questions.question:
Question 17: You are an intern posted in the ophthalmology department where you are observing a patient 
subjected to the Worth’s four-dot test. The patient is suffering from left suppression. Which 
of the following images would he most likely see?
questions.explanation:
The patient will see 2 red lights as shown in image C as he is suffering from left suppression. Worth's four-dot test is a sensory function test. A box is viewed which has four lights: one red, two 
green, and one white. The patient has to wear red-green goggles. Inference: • A: Normal—All 4 lights seen • B: Abnormal retinal correspondence—All 4 lights seen in the presence of manifest squint • C: Left Suppression—2 red lights seen • D: Right suppression—3 green lights seen • E: Diplopia—5 lights seen (2 red, 3 green)

questions.question:
Question 18: While evaluating a case of squint, an ophthalmologist does a forced duction test. What is the 
use of this test?
questions.explanation:
Forced duction test (FDT) is done to find out ocular muscle palsy. It is performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of the extraocular 
muscle and that due to the mechanical restriction of the ocular movements. Forced duction test: 460 
Sold by @itachibot • Positive in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction • Negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is true?

options.a: Direct cover test is helpful in detecting presence of heterophoria.
options.b: Alternate cover test helps to differentiate concomitant squint from paralytic squint.
options.c: Cover-uncover test confirms the presence of manifest squint.
options.d: In direct cover test, the squinted eye is covered and normal eye is uncovered.

questions.explanation:
Alternate cover test helps in differentiating concomitant squint from paralytic squint is a true 
statement. In a concomitant squint, the eye moves rapidly to fixate, whereas in a paralytic squint, 
the eye will not move to fixate.

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient presented to an ophthalmologist with complaints of crowding of words, while 
reading for long hours. The results of the test that was performed are shown below What is 
the most likely diagnosis? 449 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given test is a Maddox rod test, and the pattern of the appearance of white dot/light in 
relation to the red line denotes a case of left eye exophoria. In the given image, the above image 
refers to the examiner's view and the below image refers to the patient's view. The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in 
conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo-deviations. Interpretation: To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, 
the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction. The patient fixates a point source of 
light and then sees a vertical red line with the left eye and white dot/light with the right eye: • Orthophoria: if the light/dot superimposes the line. • Exo-deviation/exophoria: In this example, light/dot is on the left side of the line (rod placed on 
left eye) • Eso-deviation/esophoria: if the light was on the right side of the line (rod placed on left eye) Maddox Rod Test involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale. It uses a 
specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point 
source of light into a line image. The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to 
be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders. 461 
Sold by @itachibot In the image given below, the interpretation of the result is based on how the patient visualizes it. 
It would appear to be crossed to the patient. Pictorial representation of the eyes are as seen by the 
examiner. Imagine you are looking through a Maddox rod over your left eye while interpreting the 
images. 462
